Moreover, a great cloud arises and rains on the top of the golden wheel, the drops are like chariot axles, the accumulated water rushes and surges, and the water then becomes the storehouse of various precious seeds.
Due to the various powerful violent winds drilling and striking, it transforms and produces various kinds of precious things and so forth.

It is only this dharma, when at the time of transformation, the basis of the different characteristics is called the existent dharma.

It is this very thing, yet not like this. Such a statement has never been heard before.

After the transformation has produced gold, jewels, etc., by the power of karma, a separate wind is produced that separates the jewels, etc., and gathers them into masses to form the continents and mountains, and divides the fresh and salt waters to form the inner and outer oceans.
In this way the nine mountains rest on the golden wheel, and all enter the water to a depth of 80,000 yojanas. Sumeru emerges from the water to the same height.
The other eight emerge from the water to half their depth, that is, the first, Yugandhara, emerges 40,000 yojanas, and so on, until the last, Cakravada, emerges 312.5 yojanas.

Where are the hells and the great hells located?

In verse, it says:

The sixteen increases are the four places outside the four gates of the eight hells:

The first is the hell of burning embers, which is filled with burning embers to the depth of a knee. Even if they want to escape, on both banks there are prison guards holding swords and spears who ward them off and prevent them from returning, so there is no way out.

This is the place of supreme punishment and harm, so it is called increased. In the main hells, after being harmed, one is harmed again.

Now, in this context, a discussion arises from a discussion.
Are the wardens of the hells sentient beings or not?

It is in hell itself, because hell already contains the retribution produced by the uninterrupted karma. What principle is there to prohibit this?

This is definitely because their karma obstructs it, or because they are born with a different kind of coarse matter, so they are not burned.

As for the meaning of the extent of the abodes of the sun and moon, the verse says:

Why is it that at the end of the dark half and the beginning of the bright half, the moon's disk is seen to be incomplete?

Its roots extend fifty yojanas into the ground, and its trunk rises up one hundred yojanas, with branches spreading out in all directions, one hundred yojanas high and wide. This matter is not definite. All the masters of the Vinaya allow both possibilities without fault.
If this is so, why did the Bhagavat say:

This statement was made based on human fragrances, because it is commonly understood that they do not have this ability.
The scriptures of the Dharmaguptaka school say that this fragrance, when carried by the wind, fills a hundred yojanas, and when there is no wind, it fills fifty yojanas.
In the southwest corner outside is the Hall of Good Dharma, where the thirty-three celestials gather at times to discuss matters according to the Dharma and contrary to the Dharma.

How should one understand the differences in desire and pleasure?
In verse it is said:
Desire is born in the three realms of humans and gods, and pleasure is born in the three and nine realms.
The treatise states:

The three in the desire realm refer to those sentient beings who enjoy the actual present subtle desired objects. They have mastery over such present desired objects, referring to the entire human realm and the lower four heavens.

There are sentient beings who enjoy the subtle desired objects created by themselves. They have mastery over the subtle desired objects created by themselves, referring only to the fifth heaven of the Delighting in Creation.

There are sentient beings who enjoy the subtle desired objects created by others. They have mastery over the subtle desired objects created by others, referring to the sixth heaven of the Freely Partaking of Others' Creations.

Because they enjoy the desired objects that arise in the present, because they enjoy the desired objects created by themselves as they wish, and because they enjoy the desired objects created by others as they wish, the desire realm is divided into three types based on the distinctions in the desire realm.
